segments.text: And he said, my idea of democracy is that that is a government run by the people and for the people.
And I said, that's very close to my views, sir.
He said, well, then tell me, how can you run a democracy in a country where 87% of the people
can't participate.
Our literacy rate, 87% can't read and write.
How can they participate?
So they need to be told, they need to be led.
So what we're trying here is democracy for 13% of the people and 87% zero, nothing.

but yet your country demands that we do that in order for us to get aid and he says I'm going to take over this government and I said he said I'm going to follow the principles in which you have outlined here today even to moving the troops I laid out to him I laid out to him a principle of
first off, if you're going to take over a country and want the support of outside influence, don't kill anybody unless you have to.
It must be, you just don't do it.
I said, I will judge your success by the number of people that you don't kill.
He said, I understand.
I said, that's
you'll get internal support and you'll get external support if you don't do that.
I said another principle is the disposed should be handled in such a way that that they exist after this is all over with.
I said

Another thing is grab the communication center and start talking to the people and tell them exactly what you're doing and why because they deserve the right to know why you're doing this and what you expect what they should expect from the outcome.

We went through where the key communication centers are, Karachi and Lahore, and what the likely things to do in Dhaka at that time, because you had East Pakistan, where to dispose your soldiers, support you should ask for from the, from the malas, from the leaders in the villages who, from where the soldiers come, mostly.

opposition politicians don't let them don't lock them up unless it's absolutely necessary but if they do start interfering lock them up don't punish them just lock them up get them out of the way until you get yourself stabilized after about four hours
He was satisfied.
This was on March the 6th, 1958.
And he said to me, he said, if you want to tell my friend Alan Dulles, you feel free to do this.
Did you tell the head of the CIA?
Yes.
What did he, how did he respond?
He said, you have a military mind and it isn't going to happen.
That's what he said to the general or to you?
Said to me.
He wrote back and said that?
Yes.
You have a military mind and it's not going to happen?
Yeah, and that was also a reaction of the political newspaper Eisenhower appointee ambassador.
Who was the ambassador at that time?
He was a sad one, but I can't think of his name.
He ended up in a newspaper out in New Hampshire.
Oh my God.
He had an alcoholic wife.
I can't think of a worse selection to represent a president anywhere than he was, but I can't remember his name.
Why do you say that?
He was just totally inept?
Well, I think inept is he knew nothing about what?
About Pakistan.
Yeah.
Just political appointee.
Kind of like you said, you know, we won't discuss this anymore.
He said, I'd like to
Feel free to come talk to you on this, Mary Ann, in case I need to.
I said, yes, sir.
Well, you must have had an Air Force colonel there and a MAG team, and you must have had an AP, a captain probably, didn't you?
Yeah, right.
And did you inform those people?
Did you talk to those people about this?
No way.
No way.
They weren't as close to the general as you were, obviously.
Oh, there wasn't anybody in the country as close as I was to IU.
Well, why do youwhy you?
I mean, how did this come about?
Well, we were 1,200 miles away from everybody else and he had confidence in mobility.
Because the others were in Dhaka?
The others were in Karachi.
Oh, okay.
That's where the MAG headquarters was.
And we saw each other almost every day, not every day, but that's the reason for it.
I told the mag chief.
He said, I don't believe it.
Who was the mag chief?
He was a brigadier general?
No, he was a major general.
He's still alive.
I know you're making him look bad.
Okay, he didn't believe it.
And the CIA didn't believe it.
The CIA didn't believe it.
Army attache said, I'll report it, but I can't think it'll happen.
So, thank you, ma'am.
So, that cup, I guess.
Thank you very much, Mr. Donaldson.
So, you use sugar in this?
No, thank you, sir.
I don't need to tell you this, but when you see the 13th Lancers moving to where you said they should move on a training exercise, then you'll know things are imminent.
So on the 5th of October, the 13th Lancers moved from Queda to Multan.
was scheduled to go to visit that regiment in Queda.
And we got a call on the 4th of March.
Now wait a minute, you're in first, you said March.
I mean October.
You were in October, right?
I'm talking about October.
Okay, the first meeting was in March.
March the 6th.
Yes, and okay, and so now.
So then on the 5th of October,
The 13th Lancers moved to Multan, and on the 4th of October, we got a message from the headquarters at GHQ, which we were a part of.
We had a building there in the general headquarters of the Pakistani forces.
We got this message requesting us to delay our visit to the 13th Lancers.
because they had U.S. equipment, you see, and we'd go inspect it to see how well they were doing about their training.
So my deputy, Lieutenant Colonel Watson, said, I can't understand.
We ought to go back and intercede here.
We've got a schedule set up, and we've got to follow this schedule.
I said, no, they don't want us to go out there at this time, so we're not going.
Did you tell your deputy about your earlier conversation?
Oh, no, I never told anybody.
Just Dulles?
Pass the word to Allen Dulles.
And I did that through the ambassador.
Yeah.
But then word never got to Allen Dulles.
Oh, really?
No.
Word never got to the United States.
I thought you said earlier that no one believed you.
They didn't.
Ambassador didn't believe me.
But you gave the word to the ambassador.
He was supposed to report to Washington.
Absolutely.
He never did report this.
No.
So neither did the MAG chief.
As far as I know.
Or if they did, they just cast it aside.
So at 2 o'clock in the morning on the 6th of October, a coup came.
I talked to now Prime Minister, President IU many times thereafter.

He said, you know, he said, Holly, one of the most critical times in my life was when I called the Commonwealth of Nations and the ambassadors of the United States together at 2 o'clock in the morning to tell them what was going on.
and said, right down the line, the ambassador from Australia said, President Ayub, you have my country's total support.
Great Britain, you have my country, ambassador, you have my country's total support.
New Zealand, all the way right on down the line.
Canada.
Come to the United States.
And that ambassador said,
Well, what happened to Umrah?
Why wasn't Umrah promoted?
Well, now listen to this.
Umrah is either a brigadier general or a major general over command in a division in East Pakistan in which our intelligence agencies and so on and so forth thinks a real great guy.
How do you spell his name?
Umrah, U-V-M-H-R-O.
And they were sold on, this guy.

Yeah, and here, and General Ayub says, Ollie, here at a time of crisis, and all the important ambassadors and all the support I needed, that I needed, I get from one of the prime countries in the world,
a question as to why I didn't promote some general officer.
Said, this is unbelievable.
I said, Mr. President, I'm not surprised.
And I wasn't surprised.
I can't think of that joker's name.
We've had so many jokers as ambassadors, political appointees, you know, all over the place.
God, I can't think of his name now.
It's so insignificant that you try not to remember the insignificance, you know, because there's so many important things and so many good people to remember.
Write to the letter and I congratulated him after he was all over with.
Only one guy was killed and as the light tanks of the 13th Lancers were moving in Karachi to the radio station
They excited a camel cart and the camels broke loose and run over the camel driver in the street with a wagon and killed him, not from gunfire.
He took Iskander Mirza, who was the prime minister, his whole family, whole household, his whole
group of kids this and that and all kinds of hands and all that loaded them in the airplane and sent them to England and they're still in England.
How long did he lock up any opposing political parties, leaders?
Uh, you know believe it or not I think he had the general
respect and support of those people and it wasn't until he began to get sick and he was failing in health until he got a little bit cross purposes with some of the civilian people over there.
When you've got a country of 14 or 15 different damn parties
and no leadership amongst any of them.
What a shambles.
Mrs. IU was still living.
And is that why you've maintained very close contacts with the military?
in Pakistan and why you go back every once in a while and talk to the new president?
I guess so.
The new president was a major in what they called a guides cavalry.
That was probably the most famous cavalry unit in the world.
It was British, Pakistani, British Indian, and then Pakistani.
President Zia was a major in the Guides Cavalry, and I'm very fond of those officers there.
The Pakistan Military Academy is a two-year academy patterned after Sandhurst, and they do a tremendous job in selecting people for PMA, and for the curriculum there is followed almost completely.
but with nationalistic conditions.
But fighting after the British was one of the best.
Did you have any mixed feelings about your dealings?
For a couple of reasons.
First, you're a military representative and not a political representative or usually military mag personnel.

deal somewhat in politics, but not very much, and second, you are a representative of a country that's always attempting to export democracy, and so proud of its democracy, and here what you're doing eventually leads to the end of a democracy, even though it was a weak one, and the rise of a dictatorship.
Did you have any mixed feelings about your role?
No, because you just had to
You have to take our foreign policy and you just cannot allow it to destroy the common sense aspects of a democracy.
You can't be, you can't allow a democracy

to be so damn foolish and so damn wrong that you make our whole country look bad in trying to implement that policy in a part of the world where there isn't a single person with any common sense and sound judgment knows that that's what's right for that country and their people.
You just can't do that.

for people who are not schooled who can't handle it and that's what we have consistently done and this is where I'm consistently opposed to this sort of thing now we tried our best he said what are you how do you get around this business of democracy here now and when we're trying to do something for these people
I said, well, you've got to keep preaching democracy at the same time and practice it at every instant that you possibly can.
But at the same time, do something to enhance the welfare of the mass of the people in this country.
And I said, I think you can do it.
I think you can take over this country without denying the rights of everyone.
And I said, avoid that, denying the rights people deserve.
Now, some people don't deserve any rights.
Some people display themselves in such a fashion they don't deserve any rights.
Does a criminal deserve a right to run up and down the streets out here shooting at people and so on and so forth?
What kind of rights was that?
Don't you think that you deserve a right to walk up and down the streets of Dallas after midnight without being shot at?
Huh?
Can you get that?
Is that right available to you today?
I hope so.
But it isn't.
Probably.
You understand?
Yeah, I understand.
You see what I'm talking about?
So, uh...
You know, I like to look at these countries like this.
What's best for the country?
Yeah, okay.
What's best for the country?
Now, after the general became the president and took over the country, tell me about your relationship with him then.
They more or less ceased because he was out of them.
military role other than commander-in-chief and they more or less dropped off except for social and for well hunting and that sort of stuff.

He would still invite me to go with him hunting and so forth but we never sat down and had any military conferences because now you got a new commander-in-chief, General Musa, M-U-S-A, who was his deputy and he was promoted to the commander-in-chief.
So then my relationship switched directly to General Moussa again.
That's the way we worked at it.
So, in other words, you didn't advise him?
No, none at all.
None at all.
After he became president and prime minister, he moved to Karachi, where the seat of the government was, and I had no more official
contact with him on his social.
One might think that he might offer you some sort of a position behind the scenes with the government, but he never did.
No, and he knew that I wouldn't accept it anyway because he was as much a soldier as I am.
He knew.
He knows what the rules are.
Well, I meant, you know, as an alternative to your military career.
Oh, well.
Like General Chenault, working for China.
Yeah.
Before.
Right, sure, sure.
That never happened in my life.
Okay, okay.
I was wondering about an issue that happened earlier, but one that
relates to the idea of who is commander-in-chief, the politician or the general, and that is the General MacArthur and Harry Truman episode.
It does have some parallels here to what happened in Pakistan.
What was your feeling on that episode?
Did you think Truman acted correctly?
The president, by law, is a commander-in-chief.
I'm a law-abiding person and I believe in a civilian rule and I believe in a political two-party system.
I hope we don't get many more parties than that.
I believe in our whole Constitution, the whole layout, all aspects of it.
That doesn't mean that there may be some portion of it that may come up sometime that needs to be changed.
I'm not against change, but I am against just change for change's sake.
I think there must be a good specific reason that's impacting unfavorably on them
on the totality of our people before you go change the Constitution, of course.

But I've always looked up to the president, and always will, and I stand by whatever decision he makes, and I hope that he provides me an opportunity, if I'm in the right position, to participate before the decision is made.

and express my views one way or the other through now the members of the Congress or by written word or oral or whatever it might be but after the decision is made I think that everybody must this is what I believe democracy is is participating
But after the decision is made, then you support the higher authority.
And I think a general, I think anybody can serve too long and become too over-viewed with his presence.
publicly or officially.
And I think General MacArthur was long overdue for retirement.
And I would have thought that his better judgment might have dictated that to him.
So, I support Mr. Truman one thousand percent.

If a man doesn't come up and say, it's obvious Mr. President, you and I are not getting along here, I'm going to step down because I know you're not and let's do this very quietly and get on with it, okay?
What's wrong with that approach?
After 50 years in the uniform, you're supposed to leave at the end of 30.
So, I support President Truman.
Okay.
Now, why'd you leave Pakistan?
Your tour of duty was up.
Usually it's a two mags, or usually two years.
Your duty is up, and I was a colonel, and I was due for command.
Okay, okay.
And you got a deputy commander, Combat Company A.
Combat Company A, 1st Armored Division.
Where was that?
That was at Fort Hood.
Okay.
Fort Hood, and then you had that for about nine months, and then you became Chief of Staff of the 2nd Armored Division, also at Fort Hood.
Right.
That was my old World War II division.
Okay.
Okay.
What were you doing there, training?
Training completely, totally training, right.
We had a full division there, and we were training in Europe.
The division at the time I was there was scheduled for Europe, and we were putting forth all of our efforts toward deployment to that area in case of a national emergency.
Okay, and then in August of 1961, you got a new assignment.
Was that because Kennedy was elected?
Yes, yes.
Now tell me how that came about.
Well that came about after I had completed this year or 18 months down there at Fort Hood.
It came about that then I have to go to high staff, highest level staff.
That's what I'm scheduled for next.

high-level staff at the cabinet level, and so I was selected, approved by the Secretary of Defense to come to high-level staff positions, and after out there a little while, and then I became, they were satisfied, then that's when I was given the political appointee slot.
And one of the key points there during that four years was Cuban Crisis, in which I was involved in the manpower aspects of that and the calling of the reserves.
Okay, so you were Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Reserve and Manpower from August 1962 until October 1965.
Right.
Okay, let's start off right away.
Your boss is, who is your immediate supervisor?
My immediate supervisor is Assistant Secretary of Defense Norman Paul, P-A-U-L.
Okay, and of course his boss is McNamara.
His boss is McNamara.
Okay, now there's a heck of a lot of controversy about McNamara, and sometimes I hear from many generals their dislike for McNamara.
Some people have surprised me and told me what a wonderful guy he was.
He's very controversial.
You worked with him closely.
What's your opinion?
Well, I thought that Mr. McNamara was a very
smart man who was taking on a hundred billion dollar or more operation, who was trying his damnedest to bring some sense of management
to an unmanageable organization wherein you have three services fighting each other for a few dollars and that would not, even if they got all of it, would not satisfy the total requirement.
A job that, well I can't think of a tougher job than being Secretary of Defense other than being President of the United States.
And McNamara received much criticism, very little praise.

But overall, you have to give the man credit for fostering what the Colonel DeVolt had attempted to do by starting to build a conventional deterrent and to maintain some balance in the strategic deterrent

and modernizing the theater nuclear deterrent and at the same time fighting a war in Vietnam and trying to fight that war and his theory was we ought to end that war with not one nickel spent beyond what it cost to run that war in other words
When the war is over, when the ceasefire comes, or whatever it is, whoever wins, loses, or draws, the inventory should be zero at that point in time.
Of course, that's where I disagreed with him, because that indicates that that is the last of all wars, in which it's wrong, in which your security capability drops back to zero.
And you can't afford that.
But that's the dollar aspect of it.
What kind of person was he?
Can you give me sort of a description of his character?
I think he liked a lot of independence.
He didn't like too many people around.
I think he had utter disregard for people.
I mean he had no sense of feeling for people at all.
They were just something else.
They were tools.
No sense of feeling for people, and no sense of respect for the political side of America.
He thought the politicians are all little gimmicks, or he thought of things, you know, insignificance, and that sort of thing.
And that caused him a lot of misery.
But that's, when you treat them,
When you treat the politicians as a bunch of little kids, you know, that you can slap and kick around, or dogs, that's what you get.
You're asking for it.
Absolutely.
And he got it.
But I liked the man.
He never harmed me.
He'd only help.
He had very high standards of performance.
And anybody that performed well stayed there.
General Haig was there as lieutenant colonel.
I was there as a colonel.
Alexander Haig was there as a lieutenant colonel?
Oh yeah.
Oh yeah.
He worked for Mr. Joe Califano, who was chief special assistant to Mr. McNamara.
And that's when I learned, that's when I knew Joe Califano.
What did you think of him?
Just one hell of a guy.
Smart, just a tremendous guy.
What did you think of Haig?
Phenomenal lieutenant commander and battalion commander.
He was one of my battalion commanders in Vietnam in my division, Division G3, Chief of Operations as a lieutenant colonel.
And he was really good?
Oh, absolutely.
Absolutely best.
Absolutely the best.
Why?
Smart, very intense from the standpoint of learning and retention, burning desire to succeed, warm personality, respectful of others, seniors and subordinates alike.
Hello, man.
I saw him there.
Oh, you did?
Oh, yeah.
He invited me over to his house.
I went over to see him.
I spent about 45 minutes with him.
Oh, where is he?
He's in Washington.
He may eventually be in Texas.
Why do you say that?
He may say, he could, you know, accept a position down here someplace.
Um,
He was a hell of a guy, a hell of a battalion commander.
I know he was promoted because of his relations with politicians.
He was promoted over about, what, two or three hundred senior people.
Oh, yeah.
Was there some envy or jealousy or grumbling?
Always some.
Always, yeah, always some.
Like the President's Chief of Staff.
He's out of Class of 50.
Shire Meyer, he was
The black secretary jumped him over several hundred.
Those things happened.
But again, you see, you must support the system and the authority of the President of the United States or you've got nothing.
you have absolutely nothing and no security you've got to do that within the armed forces.
Now let's talk about this job itself.
You're in a political position here.
You're an assistant secretary.
This is, you know, the deputy secretary or assistant secretary is
political appointee.
That's true.
And not a military position.
This is really rare in American history.
That's true.
This might be the first case.
You must have had, being in this political slot, and being a colonel, you must have had generals who were superior.
Is that not true?
That's true.
I'm surprised you didn't have to resign your commission for this.
Tell me about the difficulty that you had, or the position itself.
I tell you, I guess that it does seem somewhat
out of order in the system.
However, I guess it's the techniques you use and how you avoid disorder and try to gain confidence and cooperation.
And I've prepared many memorandums.

particularly on the reserves, and sent to the Secretary of the Army, and the Navy, and the Air Force, and which were directive in nature that the four-star generals and the three-star generals probably didn't like worth a damn.
But all they had to do was to complain to their secretary, and he could go complain to Mr. McNamara and get thrown out

so you see when you ask me about Mr. McNamara when you work for him and he supports you you have his loyalty and respect and confidence you just get on with it and whether they like it or not and come up number 66 on three brigadier lists and they only go down and promote
64 each year, you know, for three years.
You can be on the damn list, and they'd throw the list out and start all over.
And is that what happened?
There's some of the things that happened, yeah.
Well, tell me about that.
You were numbers, when you came up for Brigadier General, you were number 66 on the list?
Yeah, first time, and they promoted down to number 63, I guess, and they threw the list out.
you know, for next year and start all over.
So, a new board comes in with slates and you end up maybe this year number 65 or something and they only promote 60.
That's all the slots that come open.
So, you come up again for promotion.
You only come up about four times.
And you come up every year?
Yeah, you come up every year for four years for the general officer.
And then last time you come up and you're number two on the list.
You get promoted almost immediately when the list comes up.
And so that's what happened.
That could be some praise.
Oh, God, you know, I don't complain about that.
I know about all that sort of stuff.
In other words, Mr. McNamara was really happy with the quality of work that you were doing.
Yeah, he was very happy.
In fact, I had my first Distinguished Service Medal, my first medal that they normally reserve for general officers, which is the highest award you can get in service, Distinguished Service Medal.
was when I was a colonel.
Why do you think that you were, when you first came up, the first time you came up for general, why do you think that you were number 66?
Especially considering your career.
Yeah, I think because whoever was on that board, whoever the six generals were on that board liked
65 guys better than they did me.
Maybe one of those guys on the board, I don't know, was the one that I forced a memorandum down his throat to get something done that he didn't like.
You see what I mean?
That's all it takes.
Records be damned.
Records be damned.

he could have said to the other five boards I wouldn't promote that son of a bitch he sends a goddamn memorandum down here raising hell with us on this that and the other because we did this wrong that wrong I wouldn't promote that bastard for anything and the others say well I don't know him but he's got a hell of a good record right hell with his record you know
It's, you know, what we're doing here is dealing with people.
Sure, right.
And I don't blame a damn bit.
Who do you think I am?
